channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: How Tim Cook Changed Apple in the 10 Years He's Been CEO
item.description: That’s right, Cook has been the CEO of Apple for exactly 10 years this week. Cook still has plenty of problems to deal with, from high-stakes legal challenges against Apple’s App Store policies to a more vocal workforce to thorny privacy questions. While the iPhone still reigns supreme, Apple has expanded its hardware lineup in the last decade and scored hits with the Apple Watch and AirPods.  Apple’s annual revenue in 2011, when Cook took over, was $108.2 billion; in 2020 it made $274.5 billion. It also made a big move into services (Apple Pay, Apple Music, etc.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Same-day Streaming Causes Movie Piracy to Ramp Up
item.description: While streaming platforms may recoup some money lost to piracy via digital rentals and subscriber growth (which has boomed for Disney+, HBO Max, and Netflix), theaters won’t see a cent of that. Black Widow was the most pirated movie in the world for three weeks running after it was released on Disney+ and in theaters on July 9, according to piracy-monitoring site TorrentFreak. What pirated movies used to look like: shaky camcorder recordings of movies taken in theaters and uploaded to piracy sites. Black Widow, The Suicide Squad, Jungle Cruise, and other would-be blockbusters simultaneously debuted in theaters and on streaming services in summer 2021. Theater owners are blaming the recent phenomenon of same-day releases for a spike in piracy.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Powell Signals the Fed Will Wind Down Stimulus Measures in the Coming Months
item.description: In a highly anticipated speech yesterday, the Fed Chair said that the economy has recovered enough that “it could be appropriate” to start slowing down some of the Fed’s pandemic-era stimulus measures.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Make It Work
item.description: Have a question about work you want to ask Shane? I like my boss, but how do I get them to stop micromanaging me? Each week, our workplace whisperer Shane Loughnane answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021. Give a little grace, if you can afford it. Be one of the first subscribers to our upcoming newsletter on all things human resources. When you get a new project, ask your boss, “What would it look like if this were done perfectly?” Does your boss know that their current style demotivates you? Ask Shane here. Finding ways to introduce resources like these can help to limit unnecessary micromanagement and strengthen leadership skills throughout your organization. —Rachel in FloridaThis seems like a fun one to crowdsource to Brew readers—anyone game to help Rachel out? HR Brew.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Icebreakers With...Happiness Expert Dr. Laurie Santos
item.description: But joking aside, I think one of the things you learn when you study primates in particular is that humans really are just animals ultimately.  The most important tip is realizing that rejection really hurts. On the one hand, pictures can help us remember things better, which helps us to access all our fondest moments. But the good news is that those self-reports are valid for happiness and well-being. Take time to write down the things you like about yourself, why you’re valued. So really the best way to know if you're happy is to ask yourself. One of the great things about being the person who teaches a happiness class is that I have to practice what I preach.  The best way to know if you're happy is to ask yourself, “How am I feeling right now?” But if taking pictures means that you're worrying about how your hair looks or forcing people out of the moment to take a picture, then they might not be such a good idea.   Santos was kind enough to grant us time during office hours to ask a few questions. Meet up with the people who really care about you, and if you can't meet up with them directly, then do some “social snacking” and just look at pictures of people who are close to you. That’ll allow you to have a memento that will help you remember after the fact.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 27
item.description: (BBC Future)  Read: How water shortages are brewing wars. Last week’s hack compromised the personal info of more than 50 million people.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Corporate America’s $50 Billion Pledge to Fight Against Racial Inequality
item.description: Last June, US corporations pledged to give a historic sum of money to projects addressing racial inequality following George Floyd’s murder.   14 months later, where and how has the money been spent? So far, 37 companies have confirmed disbursing at least $1.7 billion.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Peloton Shares Slide After Disappointing Quarter, Price Cut on Bike
item.description: Not even Cody Rigsby could cheer up Peloton after its latest earnings report. — NF before yesterday’s tumble.  After gaining more than 440% last year, shares have fallen more than 25% year-to-date...
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Supreme Court Throws Out Biden's Eviction Moratorium
item.description: Big picture: The eviction moratorium was just Part 1 of a two-pronged approach by the government to help out renters during the pandemic. But because the latest moratorium was authorized by the CDC and not by Congress, it was on legal shaky footing. The Supreme Court put an end to the moratorium that protected renters from being evicted during the pandemic. — NF Looking ahead... Problem is, Part 2 has flopped harder than Amazon's Fire Phone.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Supreme Court Throws Out Biden's Eviction Moratorium
item.description: Big picture: The eviction moratorium was just Part 1 of a two-pronged approach by the government to help out renters during the pandemic. The Supreme Court put an end to the moratorium that protected renters from being evicted from their homes during the pandemic. But because the latest moratorium was authorized by the CDC and not by Congress, it was on legal shaky footing. Looking ahead... Problem is, Part 2 has flopped harder than the ESPN phone.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Peloton Shares Slide After Disappointing Quarter, Price Cut on Bike
item.description: Not even Cody Rigsby could cheer up Peloton after its latest earnings report. before yesterday’s tumble.  After gaining more than 440% last year, shares have fallen more than 25% year-to-date...

item.title: German Publisher Axel Springer Announces Plans to Buy Politico
item.description: In May, there were whispers that Axel Springer was looking to buy Politico rival Axios, but the double-ax hasn’t come through yet. Plus, buying Politico is another way it can get into the US media market, which it’s been circling for years.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Corporate America’s $50 Billion Pledge to Fight Against Racial Inequality
item.description: Last June, US corporations pledged to give a historic sum of money to projects addressing racial inequality following George Floyd’s murder. Pledges from Corporate America are welcome, but companies aren’t accountable for their financial commitments, and in the end they must serve their shareholders before anything else. So far, 37 companies have confirmed disbursing at least $1.7 billion.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Reflecting on Tim Cook's Leadership at Apple, 10 Years On
item.description: That’s right, Cook has been the CEO of Apple for exactly 10 years this week. Cook still has plenty of problems to deal with, from high-stakes legal challenges against Apple’s App Store policies to a more vocal workforce to thorny privacy questions. While the iPhone still reigns supreme, Apple has expanded its hardware lineup in the last decade and scored hits with the Apple Watch and AirPods.  Apple’s annual revenue in 2011, when Cook took over, was $108.2 billion; in 2020 it made $274.5 billion. It also made a big move into services (Apple Pay, Apple Music, etc.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Joe Rogan Influence Diminished After Move to Spotify , the Verge Reports
item.description: Using secondary metrics, like how much of a promotional boost Rogan gave his guests, The Verge found that Rogan’s influence has diminished since he went to frolic in Spotify’s walled garden. Joe Rogan shook up the podcasting world when he brought his megapopular show exclusively to Spotify in a deal worth a reported $100 million. – NF
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 26
item.description: (NYT Magazine)  Read: Roger Federer’s biggest legacy might be his billion-dollar brand. The direct-to-consumer pioneer filed to go public on Tuesday.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: OnlyFans Goes Back on Proposed Porn Ban
item.description: OnlyFans hasn’t said whether its relationship with banks has changed, but the problems it’s facing are nothing new in the adult entertainment industry.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Delta Cracks Down on Unvaccinated Employees—but Doesn't Mandate Vaccinations
item.description: And while the airline isn’t mandating vaccinations, it’s making life frustrating for employees who are unwilling to get the shot.  It comes down to “financial risk,” CEO Ed Bastian said.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Unique Supply Chain Issues Cause Shortages in the UK
item.description: These shortages are exacerbated by one broken cog in the supply chain: a lack of truck—err, lorry—drivers. And while driver shortages are a problem in many countries, the UK’s are due to a more unusual set of circumstances than just “the pandemic.” Gas station pumps are running dry, compounding supply chain issues.  The bigger picture: The UK is facing historic shortages across the board due to supply chain snags that are hitting the country harder than the White Queen clobbered Ron. A sampling:Iconic halal chicken joint Nando’s is feeling less cheeky after closing about 50 restaurants because of poultry shortages.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Should you get into crypto? Early investors share regrets, opportunities, advice
item.description: As we have seen in the last 10 months, prices can go up four times and then go down two times. Morehead: If people want to invest in Dogecoin and it's been working for six or eight years and even more people want to invest in it 10 years from now and the value keeps going up? The estimates for the number of crypto users in the US are at around 6% of the population and in some countries that is getting closer to 10%. A lot of the users who are coming into some of the crypto games have never been in crypto before and so the games are sort of their first foray. Then a community can decide what to do with that work of art where they can decide to sell it or buy more art or commission a different artist to create a new work. They didn't hold back, weighing in on everything from crypto games and altcoins to NFTs and DAOs. Our panel included Dan Morehead, the founder and CEO of Pantera Capital, which calls itself the first U.S. institutional asset manager focused exclusively on blockchain; Jose Fernandez da Ponte, vice president and general manager of blockchain, crypto, and digital currencies at PayPal; and Ali Yahya and Arianna Simpson, both general partners working in crypto at venture capital firm Andreessen Horowitz. Simpson: I think we have seen only the very first inning of what's going to happen in NFTs. If I think about this in a five- to 10-year horizon kind of way, my expectation is that we'll see a lot of NFT use cases that have nothing to do with art and are completely different in nature. Now crypto has begun to graduate from its infrastructure phase and become ready for the application phase, where the technology is now capable of supporting real applications that can touch millions of users. As much as I've always expected crypto to become massive, the speed at which it happens is still kind of staggering. We hosted an event [recently] and I think one thing that struck me was that the people in the crowd were all really cool—much cooler than me and people like me who are crypto-native and have been in the space for a long time. I don't think there's any risk that, 10 years from now, we're going to find out blockchain didn't make it. Distributed ledger technology itself will be an asset class and it's going to disrupt a lot of things like currency. It just seemed like I should devote essentially the second half of my career to investing in it. I think 10 years from now, bitcoin is going to be an asset class and nobody is going to think anything of it. What was it like at the beginning, making the move to invest in this new thing called cryptocurrency? So I think crypto eventually becomes similar to the internet in the way that it interacts with and overlaps with different sectors. The number [of people saying that] is going down, but a lot of people still think I'm crazy.   Yahya: One thing that's surprising in a good way is that crypto is so interdisciplinarity—it brings together computer science, finance, economics, games theory, and now art. That is an important distinction—it's really bringing crypto to the forefront of people who weren't that into it before and were not necessarily tech native folks. Other use cases that are very interesting are things like digital identity. It's going to take bitcoin 20 years to do that. It’s a mechanism that you can use to organize human activity, but it's really heavyweight and you can only really do it for big things. But there's something interesting going on there. -Ed.]Yahya: The best way to think of a DAO is as the most digitally native way of organizing a community. Maybe we're too early or maybe it's a bubble right now and it's going to go down for five years before it ultimately goes up. I think that balance that we are seeing play out in the news every day is going to be one of the fundamental aspects of the speed of development. We are now entering a very interesting moment in time in which you can see more or less an inflection point for crypto. It’s just interesting to see how the technology penetrates increasingly different concentric circles. What advice do you have for people who may want to begin investing in crypto? We invested in things like stablecoins and some of the kind of financial primitives that are now part of DeFi, like Uniswap. Morehead: The current surprise is NFT pricing, but I still think NFT is really important. At the end of the day, a lot of people hold themselves back because they think they need some sort of external validation. Take a look at CryptoKitties, which really took off in 2017 and sort of catalyzed what eventually became the NFT [non-fungible token] movement and the crypto games movement. So I think the people should look at it carefully and accept that we are just at an early stage of the technology. I think that we will still need some time for that to mature. Morehead: When I got reintroduced to crypto in 2013, it was in the beginning of what would be a bubble that year. But there's a deeper way to think about it—that it’s yet another way of building a community. It's hundreds of different things and being a currency is just one of those. It's a way to move money around without paying a central third party. You end up with a lot of communities of people that believe in something very strongly. I don't think that anyone should be investing amounts of money that they cannot afford to lose.  Fernandez da Ponte: I don't think the volatility of the assets has surprised me; it’s something that you can expect in this space. We were at the beginning of what is now a very clear inflection point for crypto as a space. So I spun out and started my fund Autonomous Partners, which was really geared toward investing across the crypto space. The first one is people.  Simpson: It's the kind of thing that's very easy to dismiss. You can do it for something as small as a piece of media, and create a community around a work of art. So for me to want to leave that and go to a three-person bitcoin company was a very odd move to most people. I don't think that we are there yet, but we are getting close to that. You have to think about it as a completely new thing. But I think there are crazy prices being paid for things that, 100 years from now, people probably won't remember. In a very short period of time, the community has grown from the fundamental developments around bitcoin and ethereum to the next layer which is DeFi where you have a lot of new things that are built on those protocols that are enabling use cases that you could not think of three years ago. There are a bunch of protocols that move data around that we now call the internet. It started in the ‘70s and it's just now doing all of these cool things. Morehead: Try and get a portfolio of assets. If you have been following NFTs over the last six months, there was a lot of interest and then it felt like they disappeared for a while and now they are back.  Historically, crypto has seemed very difficult to get into or a little bit intimidating, so games are a means for people to start interacting with some of the concepts and be able to learn about it in a less threatening way. For example, I mentioned crypto games. You can approach it from the computer science or crypto-anarchist side, or you can approach it from the creative side. I tried to get Facebook to do something in crypto, but I was four or five years too early, so nothing came of it. Younger generations in particular like to attribute value to different things, so it's easy for older or more traditional investors to just be like, “Oh, this is nonsense.”  I think one of the best signs that there's something big happening is that central banks are now creating their own blockchain, which is an amazing testament to how important this is.   Simpson: My crypto journey started in Zimbabwe. Morehead: There's a lot of interesting topics in there. In reality, you're probably not going to get that.  Simpson: Crypto started as a sector unto itself, but what we're seeing is that it's becoming more of a layer of the technology stack and less of its own sector. So if you want to see where things are going, you really need to look at who's building it, because they will be the ones who put in all the hard work over periods of years or decades in order to build the future of whatever it is that is being built. Over time, you build a baseline of knowledge, so don't feel like you can’t start. Yahya: It's interesting to see how the technology has become mainstream. In the long run, we're going to look back and realize some very important pieces of work are being created right now. In the same way, we're seeing that area of overlap between crypto and other sectors. There's going to be some of that. Morehead: There was a long time where I worried about whether or not bitcoin would work or would get hacked. Big tech companies weren’t going anywhere. We continue to invest very much in infrastructure, but we have widened our lens and now focus on areas like crypto games or certain consumer facing financial applications, none of which was possible seven or eight years ago.  For the longest time, we have been in the infrastructure phase for crypto.
item.author: Colleen McFall

item.title: Unique Supply Chain Issues Cause Shortages in the UK
item.description: These shortages are exacerbated by one broken cog in the supply chain: a lack of truck—err, lorry—drivers. The UK is facing historic shortages across the board due to supply chain snags that are hitting the country harder than the White Queen clobbering Ron. A sampling:Iconic halal chicken joint Nando’s is feeling less cheeky after closing about 50 restaurants because of poultry shortages. And while driver shortages are a problem in many countries, the UK’s are due to a more unusual set of circumstances than just “the pandemic.” Gas station pumps are running dry, compounding supply chain issues.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: OnlyFans Goes Back on Proposed Porn Ban
item.description: Yesterday, the adult entertainment platform said it would “suspend” that ban after facing backlash for abandoning the sex workers who built the platform.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Joe Rogan Influence Diminished After Move to Spotify , the Verge Reports
item.description: Using secondary metrics, like how much of a promotional boost Rogan gave his guests, The Verge found that Rogan’s influence has diminished since he went to frolic in Spotify’s walled garden. Joe Rogan shook up the podcasting world when he brought his megapopular show exclusively to Spotify in a deal worth a reported $100 million.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 26
item.description: (NYT Magazine)  Read: Roger Federer’s biggest legacy might be his billion-dollar brand. The company, a pioneer in the direct-to-consumer industry, filed to go public on Tuesday.

item.title: Delta Cracks Down on Unvaccinated Employees—but Doesn't Mandate Vaccinations
item.description: And while the airline isn’t mandating vaccinations, it’s making life frustrating for employees who are unwilling to get the shot.  It comes down to “financial risk,” CEO Ed Bastian said.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Money Matters: Getting the Right Mix
item.description: How much money should I be investing and saving in cash every month? Keep enough cash to cover three to six months of expenses in a savings account that you can tap in the face of financial hardship. But cash comes first. Perhaps only Elon Musk appears in this newsletter as much as inflation, which is just one reason not to hoard more cash than is necessary.
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: TikTok Partners with Shopify to Add In-app Shopping Feature
item.description: As more social media platforms roll out shopping features, the US social commerce industry is expected to reach $50 billion in annual sales by 2023, per eMarketer. Facebook’s social commerce platform, Marketplace, hit 1 billion users in April. The partnership reflects a new era of "social commerce.” – SQ Looking ahead...
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 25
item.description: (Neo.life)  Read: A portrait of a professional baby maker. He’s asking that visitors avoid coming to Hawaii on vacation through the end of October to reduce the spread of Covid-19.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Waymo Launches Robotaxi Service in San Francisco
item.description: – NF+ For more self-driving car news, sign up for Emerging Tech Brew. Waymo’s service is not that popular in Phoenix, according to Emerging Tech Brew, and this week even the bombastic Elon Musk admitted that Tesla’s Full-Self Driving tech is “actually not great.”
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Airbnb Opens Its Doors to Afghan Refugees
item.description: Congress added 8,000 “special immigrant visas” intended for Afghan nationals who work for the US government, and the Biden administration told humanitarian groups to prepare for as many as 50,000 Afghan refugees who aren’t eligible for that visa to enter the US under a new designation called “humanitarian parole.”
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Maersk Makes Biggest Step Yet to Decarbonize the Shipping Industry
item.description: Maersk, the world’s largest container shipping company, is placing a $1.4 billion order for eight new ships that run on carbon-neutral fuel.  Maersk’s new ships run on carbon-neutral methanol, which is produced from renewable sources like biomass. – NF  This is about way more than shipping linesAny company that sends goods across oceans (aka most of the big ones) is feeling pressure from consumers to give their supply chains a green paint job. Commodities trader Cargill is even adding sails to some of its cargo ships to get a wind boost.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Airbnb Opens Its Doors to Afghan Refugees
item.description: Congress added 8,000 “special immigrant visas” intended for Afghan nationals who work for the US government, and the Biden administration told humanitarian groups to prepare for as many as 50,000 Afghan refugees who aren’t eligible for that visa to enter the US under a new designation called “humanitarian parole.”
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: TikTok Partners with Shopify to Add In-app Shopping Feature
item.description: The partnership reflects a new era of "social commerce.” Facebook’s social commerce platform, Marketplace, hit 1 billion users in April. – SQ Looking ahead...  “Just imagine kids 20 years from now—they’re going to be shocked to hear that we had to use a search engine when buying something,” Jet.com founder Marc Lore told the Brew.
item.author: Sherry Qin

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 25
item.description: (Neo.life)  Read: A portrait of a professional baby maker. He’s asking that visitors avoid coming to Hawaii on vacation through the end of October to reduce the spread of Covid-19.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Waymo Launches Robotaxi Service in San Francisco
item.description: If you are chosen, you will need to sign an NDA to keep quiet about your experience.   + For more self-driving car news, sign up for Emerging Tech Brew. Zoom out: While Waymo’s announcement is a step forward, autonomous vehicles face a road more winding than Lombard Street.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Maersk Makes Biggest Step Yet to Decarbonize the Shipping Industry
item.description: Maersk, the world’s largest container shipping company, is placing a $1.4 billion order for eight new ships that run on carbon-neutral fuel.    Maersk’s new ships run on carbon-neutral methanol, which is produced from renewable sources like biomass.  The new ships, which are expected to be delivered by 2024, are more electric F-150 than Nissan Leaf. Commodities trader Cargill is even adding sails to some of its cargo ships to get a wind boost.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Schools Face Severe Bus Driver Shortage as School Year Kicks Off
item.description: Among the many challenges school districts are facing this fall, a severe bus driver shortage is at the top of the list.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: August 24
item.description: At Starbucks, Pumpkin Cream Cold Brew outsold the Pumpkin Spice Latte last year. (New Yorker) What’s the secret? Read: Costa Ricans live longer than us.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Richard Branson’s Virgin Orbit to Go Public at $3.2 Billion Valuation
item.description: Not to be confused with its sister company Virgin Galactic, Virgin Orbit sends small satellites, not people, to low-earth orbit using modified Boeing 747 jets.   Virgin Orbit will use its capital infusion to try and catch up to Elon Musk’s SpaceX, the most active US rocket launcher.
item.author: Sherry Qin
